translated: Jātaka
Pañcakanipāta
Maṇikuṇḍalavagga
Uraga Jātaka
“Like a snake that sheds its skin,
he goes on, leaving behind his body;
So when the body is dissolved,
and the dead man has passed away,
The burning one does not know
the lamentations of his relatives;
Therefore I do not grieve for him,
he has gone to his own destination.”
“He did not invite you to come from there,
nor did he ask you to go from here;
He went as he came,
so why lament?
The burning one does not know
the lamentations of his relatives;
Therefore I do not grieve for him,
he has gone to his own destination.”
“If I were to grieve and wither away,
what would be the point of that for me?
For my relatives, friends, and loved ones,
there would be even more distress.
The burning one does not know
the lamentations of his relatives;
Therefore I do not grieve for him,
he has gone to his own destination.”
“Just as a child cries after the moon,
following it as it goes;
So it is with one who grieves for the dead,
who is incomplete in this way.
The burning one does not know
The lamenting of relatives,
Therefore I do not grieve,
he has gone to his destination.”
“Just as a water pot,
broken, cannot be restored,
So it is with one who grieves for the dead,
he is destroyed.
Burning, he does not know,
the lamenting of relatives,
Therefore I do not grieve,

original: gato so tassa yā gatī”ti.🔽Uragajātakaṁ catutthaṁ.
analyzed: gataḥ saḥ tassa yā gatī iti 🔽uraga jātakam
translated: he has gone to his destination.”🔽The Uraga Jātaka is the fourth.
